transcripts.message:
Declaration

In order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress of the 7th July 1838.

State of New York
Oneida County ss.

On this 21st day of October in the Year of Our Lord, One Thousand Eight hundred and fifty two, personally appeared before the Honorable Ralph N Smith first special Surrogate and Justices of a court of Record in for the County of Oneida, and State of New York aforesaid Mary House aged sixty-eight years, a resident of said Oneida in the County of Oneida, who being duly sworn according to Law doth upon her oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefits of the provisions made by the act of Congress passed 15th May 1828 entitled Pension granted to all the officers who served to the end of the Revolutionary war in the continental army, also the act of Congress passed July 7th 1838. entitled an act granting half pay and pension to Certain widows & the other acts of Congress extending said act.

That she is the widow of John House deceased who was a private in the Revolutionary war in a Company commanded first by Captain Andrew Finks, and afterwards in or near the latter part of said war by Captain Siliz in the first Military Regiment of the second five Regiments of the New York Troops in the Continental Line Commanded by Colonel Goose Van Schaick. That he enlisted sometime in or about the Month of January or February in the Year of Our Lord Seventeen

in the first Military Regiment of the original
Five Regiments of New York troops in the

transcripts.message:
Declaration,

In order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress of the 7th July 1838.

State of New York
Oneida County ss.

On this 21st day of October in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fifty two, personally appeared before the Honorable Ralph W. Entuist a special Surrogate and Justice of a Court of Record in and for the County of Oneida and State of New York aforesaid Lucy House aged sixty 68 years, a resident of Paris in the County of Oneida, who being duly sworn according to law doth upon her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefits of the provisions made by the act of Congress passed 7th of July 1838 entitled “Pension granted to all the officers who served to the end of the Revolutionary war” in the Continental army, also the act of Congress passed July 7th, 1838, entitled “An act granting half pay and pension to Certain widows & the other acts of Congress extending said act. That she is the widow of John House deceased who was a private in the Revolutionary war in a company commanded first by Captain Andrew Frinks, and afterwards and near the latter part of said war, by Captain Gates in the first Military Regiment of the second five regiments of the New York Troops in the Continental Line Commanded by Colonel Goose Van Schaick: That he enlisted some time in or about the month of January or February in the year of Our Lord Seventeen

transcripts.message:
Deposition of John JOHNSTON

State of Tennessee
Hawkins County

On this 12th day of March 1833 personally appeared before me John GRAVES, a Justice of the Peace in and for said County, John JOHNSTON aged seventy eight years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress passed June 7th 1832.

That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated. He first entered the service as a volunteer in the Militia of Washington County North Carolina in the Company commanded by Captain James MILLER, the Company was attached to a Regiment commanded by Colonel Benjamin CLEVELAND; that he volunteered and marched to King's Mountain in the State of South Carolina where they had an engagement with the British Troops under the command of General Ferguson on the 7th day of October 1780, he was in this Battle and continued in actual service in said Company and Regiment until they were discharged after the above mentioned battle. He further states that he again volunteered as a Minute man in Washington County North Carolina in Captain William WILSON'S Company attached to a Regiment commanded by Colonel Joseph HERRIN, that he marched from home on the 12th day of February 1781 and continued in actual service until they were discharged which was about the middle of April 1781. He further states that after this time he volunteered again as a Minute man in Washington County North Carolina in Captain Joseph BROWN'S Company attached to a Regiment commanded by Colonel Thomas STODDARD, he marched from home on the 20th day of July 1781 and continued in actual service until they were discharged which was about the last of August following. He further states that after this time he volunteered again as a Minute man in Washington County North Carolina in Captain Joseph BROWN'S Company attached to a Regiment commanded by Colonel Thomas STODDARD, he marched from home on the 20th day of July 1781 and continued in actual service until they were discharged which was about the last of August following. He further states that while in this last mentioned tour of service, they had an engagement with a party of British Troops under the command of Colonel Tarleton on the 20th day of August 1781 at a place called Elizabethtown in the State of North Carolina where there was considerable skirmishing and loss on both sides. He further states that he volunteered again as a Minute man in Washington County North Carolina in Captain Joseph BROWN'S Company attached to a Regiment commanded by Colonel Thomas STODDARD, he marched from home on the 20th day of July 1781 and continued in actual service until they were discharged which was about the last of August following. He further states that while in this last mentioned tour of service, they had an engagement with a party of British Troops under the command of Colonel Tarleton on the 20th day of August 1781 at a place called Elizabethtown in the State of North Carolina where there was considerable skirmishing and loss on both sides.

He further states that he knows of no person by whom he can prove his services except John GRAHAM, James CALDWELL & William KIRKPATRICK all of whom are now dead. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of any agency in any State.

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid.

John JOHNSTON

And the said John GRAVES, Justice of the Peace for said County do hereby certify that I have no interest, direct or indirect, in the prosecution of this claim.

John GRAVES
Justice of the Peace
